turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: A Federal offense.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Get back there! He'll see you!

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: I'm not shy. I've been looked at before.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: It's not an ordinary look. It's the kind of look a man gives when he's afraid somebody might be watching him.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Goodbye, Mr. Jefferies. I'll see you tomorrow.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Stella, I -- I can't tell you what a welcome sight this is. No wonder your husband's still in love with you.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Police?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: You called the police?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Oh. Well, yes and no. It wasn't an official call. He's just a friend.  An old, ornery friend.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: I'm just going to get the name of their truck!

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I'll watch the alleyway -- in case it goes that way.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Mrs. Thorwald?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Uh-uh. The dog. I think I know now why Thorwald killed it.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: You mean the one the dog was sniffing around?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: And digging in.  Look at that flower bed.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: There's a dip at this end. And since when do flowers grow shorter in two weeks?

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: There's something buried there.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: You shouldn't have let her do that! If he ever --

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Look!

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Thank heaven that's over!

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I have a feeling we've just begun.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: I wonder.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Miss Lonely Hearts just laid out something that looks like sodium trieckonal capsules.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: You can tell that from here?

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: I handled enough of those red pills to put everybody in New Jersey asleep for the winter.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Would four of them -- ?

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: No -- but it makes the rest easy to take. And she's reading the Bible.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Then I wouldn't worry too much. But let's keep an eye on her.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: You know? You might not be too bad a bargain for Lisa after all.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: You don't say! I might just take that compliment as an insult.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: What are you two talking about?

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Got a shovel?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: There's probably one in the basement.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Now wait a minute --

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: You know, Miss Fremont -- he might just have something there.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: There's no point in taking unnecessary chances.  Give me the phone book, Lisa.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: What's she trying to do? Why doesn't she turn him in?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Smart girl.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Smart? She'll be arrested!

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: That'll get her out of there, won't it?

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: When you took your first snapshot -- did you ever think it would bring you to this?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Stella -- how long do you think he'll stay there?

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Unless he's dumber than I think, he won't wait 'til his lease is up.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: What do you need money for?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: To bail Lisa out of jail.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: One hundred and twenty-seven.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: How much do you think you'll need?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: First offense burglary --  -- probably two-fifty.  The piggy bank.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Ten here.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Thirty-three here. Totals one-ninety. Not enough.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: I got twenty or so in my purse. Give me what you've got.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: What about the rest?

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: When those cops get a look at Miss Fremont -- they'll even contribute.

turns.speaker: MRS. DOYLE
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Mrs. Doyle?

turns.speaker: MRS. DOYLE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Jeff again.  Has Tom come in yet?

turns.speaker: MRS. DOYLE
turns.text: Not yet, Jeff.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: You haven't even heard from him?

turns.speaker: MRS. DOYLE
turns.text: Not a word.

turns.speaker: MRS. DOYLE
turns.text: It is something really important, Jeff?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I'm afraid it is, Tess.

turns.speaker: MRS. DOYLE
turns.text: I'll have him call the moment I hear from him.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Tell him not to waste time calling. To get over here soon as he can. I think Thorwald's pulling out tonight.

turns.speaker: MRS. DOYLE
turns.text: Who's Thorwald?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: He knows.  Don't worry, Tess. It's a man.

turns.speaker: MRS. DOYLE
turns.text: Goodnight, you idiot.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Goodnight, Mrs Doyle.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: How's your leg?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Mmmm -- hurts a little.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: And your stomach?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Empty as a football.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: And you love life?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Not too active.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Anything else bothering you?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: The Lisa Fremont who never wears the same dress twice?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Only because it's expected of her.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Depends on the quote. Let's see -- there's the plane tickets over, import duties, hidden taxes, profit markups --

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: -- A steal at eleven hundred dollars.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: That dress should be listed on the stock exchange.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: We sell a dozen a day in this price range.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Who buys them? Tax collectors?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Something big going on somewhere?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Going on right here. It's a big night.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: It's just a run-of-the-mill Monday. The calendar's loaded with them.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: It's opening night of the last depressing week of L. B. Jefferies in a cast.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Hasn't been any big demand for tickets.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Picked it up in Shanghai -- which has also seen better days.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: It's cracked -- and you never use it. And it's too ornate. I'm sending up a plain, flat silver one -- with just your initials engraved.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Now that's no way to spend your hard- earned money!

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I wanted to, Jeff.  Oh!

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: What would you think of starting off with dinner at the "21"?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: You have, perhaps, an ambulance outside?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Big enough?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Fine. Corkscrew's on the right.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I couldn't think of anything more boring and tiresome than what you've been through. And the last week must be the hardest.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Yeah -- I want to get this thing off and get moving.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Well, I'm going to make this a week you'll never forget.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: What a day I've had!

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Tired?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Not a bit. I was all morning in a sales meeting. Then over to the Waldorf for a quick drink with Madame Dufresne -- just over from Paris. With some spy reports. Back to the "21" for lunch with the Harper's Bazaar people -- that's when I ordered dinner. Then two Fall showings -- twenty blocks apart. Then I had to have a cocktail with Leland and Slim Hayward -- we're trying to get his next show.  Then I had to dash back and change.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Tell me -- what was Slim Hayward wearing?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: She looked very cool. She had on a mint green --

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: You can't buy that kind of publicity.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: That's good news.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Someday you might want to open up your own studio here.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: How could I run it from say -- Pakistan?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Jeff -- isn't it time you came home? You could pick your assignment.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I wish there was one I wanted.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Make the one you want.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: You mean leave the magazine?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: For what?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: For yourself -- and me.  I could get you a dozen assignments tomorrow... fashion, portraits --

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Don't laugh. -- I could do it!

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: That's what I'm afraid of.  Could you see me -- driving down to the fashion salon in a jeep -- wearing combat boots and a three day beard?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I could see you looking handsome and successful in a dark blue flannel suit.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Let's not talk any more nonsense, huh?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: That's what is know as "manless melancholia."

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Miss Lonely Hearts. At least that's something you'll never have to worry about.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Oh? You can see my apartment all the way up on 63rd street?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Not exactly -- but we have a little apartment here that's probably about as popular as yours.  You, of course, remember Miss Torso.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Well, she picked the most prosperous looking one.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: She's not in love with him -- or any of them.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: How can you tell that -- from here?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: You said it resembled my apartment, didn't you?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Oh... some songwriter. In the studio apartment. Lives alone. Probably had an unhappy marriage.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I think it's enchanting.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Almost as if it were being written especially for us.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: No wonder he's having so much trouble with it.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: If you're saying all this just because you don't want to tell me the truth, because you're hiding something from me, then maybe I can understand --

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: There's nothing I'm hiding. It's just that --

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: It doesn't make sense to me. What's so different about it here from over there, or any place you go, that one person couldn't live in both places just as easily?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Some people can. Now if you'll let me explain --

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: What is it but traveling from one place to another, taking pictures? It's just like being a tourist on an endless vacation.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: All right. That's your opinion. You're entitled to it, but --

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: It's ridiculous for you to say that it can only be done by a special, private little group of anointed people.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Lisa, simmer down -- will you?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: You can't fit in here -- I can't fit in there. According to you, people should be born, live an die on the same --

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Lisa! Shut up!

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Did you ever eat fish heads and rice?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Of course not.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: You might have to, if you went with me. Ever try to keep warm in a C-54, at fifteen thousand feet, at twenty below zero?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Oh, I do that all the time. Whenever I have a few minutes after lunch.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Ever get shot at, run over, sandbagged at night because people got unfavorable publicity from your camera?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Those high heels would be a lot of use in the jungle -- and those nylons and six-ounce lingerie --

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Three.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Well, they'd be very stylish in Finland -- just before you froze to death. Begin to get the idea?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Huh? Try and find a raincoat in Brazil. Even when it isn't raining  Lisa, on this job you carry one suitcase. Your home is the available transportation. You sleep rarely, bathe even less, and sometime the food you even look at when they were alive!

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Jeff, you don't have to be deliberately repulsive just to impress me I'm wrong.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: If anything, I'm making it sound good.  Let's face it, Lisa... you aren't made for that kind of a life. Few people are.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: You don't think either one of us could ever change?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Right now, it doesn't seem so.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: And it's deflating to find out that the only way I can be part of it -- is to take out a subscription to your magazine. I guess I'm not the girl I thought I was.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: There's nothing wrong with you, Lisa. You have the town in the palm of your hand.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Not quite -- it seems.  Goodbye, Jeff.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: You mean "goodnight."

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I mean what I said.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Can't we just sort of keep things status quo?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Without any future?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I'm not exactly on the other side of the room.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Your mind is. And when I want a man, I want all of him.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Don't you ever have any problems?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I have one now.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: So do I.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Tell me about it.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Why would a man leave his apartment three times, on a rainy night, with a suitcase? And come back three times?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: He likes the way his wife welcomes him home.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Not that salesman's wife. And why didn't he go to work today?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Homework. It's more interesting.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: What's interesting about a butcher's knife and a small saw wrapped up in a newspaper?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Nothing, thank heaven.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Why hasn't he gone into his wife's bedroom all day?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I wouldn't dare answer that.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Lisa -- there's something terribly wrong.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Something too frightful to utter.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Jeff -- if you could only see yourself.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Now, Lisa --

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Sitting around, looking out a window to kill time, is one thing -- but doing it the way you are --  -- with, with binoculars, and with wild opinions about every little movement you see -- is, is diseased!

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Do you think I consider this recreation?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I don't know what you consider it -- but if you don't stop it, I'm getting out of here.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: You'd better before you catch the disease!

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: What is it you're looking for?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I want to find out what's wrong with the salesman's wife. Does that make me sound like a madman?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: What makes you think something's wrong with her?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: A lot of things. She's an invalid who needs constant care -- and yet the husband nor anyone else has been in there all day.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Maybe she died.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Where's the doctor -- the undertakers?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: She could be under sedatives, sleeping.  He's in the room now.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Lisa, please!

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: There's nothing to see.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: There is -- I've seen things through that window! Bickering, family fights, mysterious trips at night, knives, saws, rope -- and since last evening, not a sight or sound of his wife! Now you tell me where she is and what she's doing!

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Maybe he's leaving his wife. I don't know, and I don't care. Lots of people have saws, knives and ropes around their houses. Lots of men don't speak to their wives all day. Lots of wives nag, and men hate them, and trouble starts -- but very, very, very few of them end up in murder -- if that's what you're thinking.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: It's pretty hard to stay away from that word isn't is?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: You could see all the things he did, couldn't you?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: What are you getting at?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: You could see that he did because he had the shades in his apartment up, and walked along the corridor, and the streets and the backyard?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Jeff, do you think a murderer would let you see all that? That he shouldn't keep his shades down and hide behind them?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: That's where he's being clever. Acting nonchalant.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: And that's where you're not being clever. He wouldn't parade his crime in front of the open shades.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: No comment.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Don't you see how silly you're being?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Okay, Lisa -- probably you're right. He's probably in the bedroom now, entertaining his wife with the indian rope trick. I'll admit to criminal insanity. Now when do I start the cure?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: The name on the second floor rear mailbox reads Mr. And Mrs. Lars, that's L-A-R-S, Lars Thorwald.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: What's the apartment house number?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: 125 West Ninth Street.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Okay, chief. What's my next assignment.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: To get on home.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: All right -- but what's he doing now?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: It doesn't seem to be in any hurry.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: He was just laying all his things out on one of the beds! Coats, suits, shirts, sox, even his wife's --

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: That alligator bag his wife had on the bedpost --

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: What about it?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: He had it hidden in the dresser! Well, at least it was in there. He took it out, went to the phone and called somebody long distance. -- His wife's jewelry was in the handbag. And something about it worried him. He was asking somebody advice over the phone.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Someone not his wife?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I never saw him ask her for advise before.  But she volunteered plenty.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I wonder where he's going now?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Suppose he doesn't come back again?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: He will. All his things are still piled on the bed.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Well, I guess it's safe to put on some lights now.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Not yet!

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: All day long I've tried to keep my mind on work.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Thinking about Thorwald?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: And you, and you friend Doyle --  Did you hear from him again -- since he left?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Not a word. He was going to check on the railroad station, and the trunk. He must be still on it.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Something on your mind, Lisa?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: It doesn't make sense to me.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: What doesn't?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Women aren't that unpredictable.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Lisa -- I can't guess what you're thinking.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: A woman has a favorite handbag -- it always hangs on her bedpost where she can get at it. Then she takes a trip and leaves it behind. Why?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Because she didn't know she was going on a trip -- and where she was going she wouldn't need a handbag.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: But only her husband would know that.  And the jewelry! Women don't keep all their jewelry in a purse, all tangled, getting scratched and twisted up.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Do they hide it in their husband's clothes?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: They do not! And they don't leave it behind them. A woman going anywhere but the hospital would always take makeup, perfume and jewelry.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Inside stuff?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Basic equipment. You don't leave it behind in your husband's drawer in your favorite handbag.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I'm with you, sweetie, but Detective Thomas J. Doyle has a pat answer for that.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: That Mrs. Thorwald left at six ayem yesterday with her husband?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: That's what the witnesses told him.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Well, I have a pat rebuttal for Mr. Doyle -- that couldn't be Mrs. Thorwald -- or I don't know women.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Still -- those witnesses.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: We'll agree they saw a woman -- but she wasn't Mrs. Thorwald. -- That is, yet.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I'd like to see your friend's face when we tell him. He doesn't sound like much of a detective.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Don't be too hard on him. He's a steady worker. I wish he'd get there, though.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Don't rush me. We have all night.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: We have all -- what?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Night. I'm going to stay with you.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: You'll have to clear that through my landlord --

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I have the whole weekend off.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Well that's fine, but I only have one bed, and --

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Say anything else, and I'll stay tomorrow night too.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Lisa, I won't be able to give you any --

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: You said I'd have to live out of one suitcase  I'll bet yours isn't this small?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: That's a suitcase?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: A Mark Cross overnight case, anyway. Compact, but ample enough.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I'll trade you -- my feminine intuition for a bed for the night.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I'd be no better than Thorwald, to refuse.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: From his landlord -- once a month.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: It's utterly beautiful.  I wish I could be creative.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: You are. You have a talent for creating difficult situations.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I do?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Staying the night here, uninvited.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Surprise -- is the most important element of attack.  And beside, you're not up on your private eye literature. When they're in trouble, it's always their Girl Friday who gets them out of it.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: The same girl who keeps him out of the clutches of seductive show girls, and over-passionate daughters of the rich.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: The same.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: But he never ends up marrying her. Strange.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Weird.  Why don't I slip into something comfortable?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: You mean -- like the kitchen? And make us some coffee?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Exactly what I had in mind -- along with some brandy.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I hate funny exit lines.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Who was the trunk addressed to?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Do you suppose it's ethical to watch a man with binoculars, and a long- focus lens -- until you can see the freckles on the back of his neck, and almost read his mail -- do you suppose it's ethical even if you prove he didn't commit a crime?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I'm not much on rear window ethics.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Of course, they have the same chance. They can look at me like a bug under glass, if they want to.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Jeff -- if anybody walked in here, I don't think they'd believe what they see.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: You and me with long faces -- plunged into despair -- because we find out that a man didn't kill his wife. We're two of the most frightening ghouls I've ever known.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Whatever happened to that old saying "Love Thy Neighbor."

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I think I'll start reviving it tomorrow, with say -- Miss Torso for a start?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Did Mr. Doyle think I stole this case.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: No, Lisa -- I don't think he did.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I'll rephrase the question.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Do you like it?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Well, -- if there was one less thread this way --  -- and two less that way --  -- I might give up bachelorhood.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: For a minute, Doyle almost had me convinced I was wrong.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: But you're not?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: In the whole courtyard, only one person didn't come to the window.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Do you think this was worth waiting all day to see?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Is he cleaning house?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: He's washing down the bathroom walls.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: It's just a picture of the backyard, that's all.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I know. But there's one important change. The flowers in Thorwald's pet flower bed.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Something's in there. Those flowers have been taken up, and put back again.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: It could be -- the knife, and the saw.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Wasn't that close?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Too close.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Suppose Mrs. Thorwald's wedding ring was among the jewelry he has in the handbag.  During that phone conversation he held up three rings -- one with a diamond -- one with a big stone of some kind -- and one plain gold band.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: And the last thing she'd leave behind would be her wedding ring!  Do you ever leave yours at home?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Jeff, if you're squeamish, just don't look.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Now hold on. I'm not a bit squeamish about what might be under those flowers -- but I don't care to watch two women end up like that dog --

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: What for?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Maybe I can get Thorwald out of the apartment.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I'll try to give you at least fifteen minutes.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Chelsea 2-7099.  We scared him once. Maybe we can scare him again.  I'm using that word "we" a little too freely, I guess. I don't take any of the chances.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Shall we vote him in, Stella?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Get an ambulance.  Don't move. Try to lie still.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Lisa -- I -- I -- can't tell you how scared I was that you -- you might --

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Shut up. I'm all right.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Think you've got enough for a search warrant now?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: A man is assaulting a woman at one two five west ninth street. Second floor rear. Make it fast.

turns.speaker: POLICE
turns.text: Your name?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: L. B. Jefferies.

turns.speaker: POLICE
turns.text: Phone number?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Chelsea 2-5598.

turns.speaker: POLICE
turns.text: Two minutes.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Steady Marlon!

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: Wanna make the colored lights go around and around?

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: A new disease.

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: Friend of yours?

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: I'm glad they let you out.

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: Nobody chickened.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: I heard about it.  You're lucky he lived.

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: They always live.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Buzzie--we better get out of here.

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: What's eating you, Judy?  You want him alive?

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Feel okay?

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: Give me some dirt.

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: What's happening?

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Good luck, Buzz.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You know something?

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You watch too much television.

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: Hey, he's real abstract and different.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I'm cute, too.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Meaning me?

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Chicken?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I thought only punks fought with knives.

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: Who's fighting?  This is the test, man.  It's a crazy game.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Machismo?

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: Somebody find him a knife.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You satisfied or you want more?

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: How 'bout you?  Say the word and you're cold, Jack--you're dead.
